page.name: RAISE Algebra 1
page.content:
Introduction

The Rice Algebra Initiative for Success and Equity (RAISE) brings together educators, researchers, content developers, and software developers to realize positive change in high school Algebra teaching and learning. We aspire to utilize OpenStax technology alongside high-quality, open-licensed (free!) content to identify and improve the content interventions that best support Black students, Latinx students, and students experiencing poverty, ultimately leading to improved academic outcomes for this priority group.

We will achieve this outcome through three key tools - content, technology, and research

  • Content: an innovative, digital Algebra 1 curriculum aligned to the Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)
  • Technology: a data-driven learning space designed for developing, validating, and innovating educational interventions that contribute to student engagement, interactivity and success
  • Research: a research partnership model that co-develops research questions to evaluate the impact of content implemented, and recommend changes for improvement

Instructional Approach

Units

As students commence each unit, we want to help them answer these three questions.

  • Why should I care?
    • Introduction video highlighting:
      • Real-world application
      • Careers
      • Racial/cultural diversity
  • How does this fit?
    • Concept Map for the course that includes a section for each unit.
  • Am I ready to learn this?
    • Getting Ready lessons that focus on foundational skills.

Unit-level resources for the teacher:

  • Unit outline and narrative
  • TEKS Alignments
  • SEL playbook
  • Project hooks

Lessons

Student-facing elements (and primary source):

  • Lesson targets as “I can…” statements
  • Content to support in-class lessons
  • Instructional videos
  • Embedded digital tools
  • Vocabulary supports
  • Extra reference content
  • Extra practice problems

Teacher support:

  • Lesson plan
  • Guidance for differentiation
  • TEKS alignment

Assessment Strategy

An effective assessment strategy for a secondary math course must balance three elements: Formative assessment that informs instruction, summative assessment that ascertains mastery, and filling a grade book with meaningful grades that communicate each student’s achievement.

Assessment Type Glossary

Unit Readiness Diagnostic

Readiness for each unit will be assessed at the start of the unit. This will allow the teacher and student to identify and remediate foundational skills/concepts that are critical at time of need. Though an adaptive assessment is possible, it doesn’t really make sense for something like this. We want to see where they are vis-a-vis each foundational skill. Each unit will have an instructional day devoted to this diagnostic and bridging readiness gaps. Students who don’t have any gaps can be given time to explore topics of interest to them.

  • Frequency/Location in Course: 1 at beginning of each unit
  • Purpose: Assess student’s readiness for unit. Will inform teacher differentiation/support for student. Note: Be sure to include “I don’t know” as an option. 
  • Item formats: Computer-scored MCSR, MCMR, with end-of-test feedback 
  • Length: 6–10 questions covering 3–5 critical prerequisite skills 
  • Content: prerequisite skills for upcoming unit 
  • Result: Provide “traffic light” report to student and teacher for each student’s readiness relative to each standard. (no points/grade)

Check-Ins

Each lesson will have formative assessment items scattered throughout. These will help students self-monitor, and teachers gauge the efficacy of their instruction. Some items will be embedded within the lesson content. Some could be exit ticket items given at the end of the lesson.

  • Frequency/Location in Course: 2-3 questions. In addition to specific questions about the content, also ask more open-ended questions like “what is not clear to you?” or “what are you confused about?” 
  • Purpose: Student self-evaluation 
  • Item formats: Computer-scored MCSR with wrong-answer feedback 
  • Length: 1 or 2 questions per check-in 
  • Content: skills/concepts just covered in lesson 
  • Result: Provide feedback to student only (no points/grade); purely formative

Section Quiz

Each unit is broken into 2-4 sections, each of which contains a few (3-6?) lessons. A quiz at the end of each section will help reduce the weight of unit tests, and can serve a formative purpose as well. Giving students some time to process new information (as well as forget it a little) will give the teacher more valuable formative information than quizzing students right after they have “learned” something.

  • Frequency: 1 per section 
  • Purpose: Assess student’s mastery of section content and inform immediate changes to instruction. 
  • Item formats: Computer-graded MCSR, MCMR, TEI where appropriate 
  • Length: 5-10 questions 
  • Content: skills/ideas from section 
  • Result: Grade (1 point per question)

Unit Test

Each unit spans about 2-4 weeks of class time. This is a good time to assess all standards from the unit, including those that are best assessed with open response item types.

  • Frequency: 1 per unit 
  • Purpose: Assess how well each student has mastered unit content. 
  • Item formats: 2-part: Computer-graded MCSR, MCMR and Teacher-graded open response 
  • Length: 12-15 computer-scored questions and 2-3 teacher-graded questions 
  • Content: skills/ideas from entire Unit 
  • Result: Grade

Semester Test

A semester test is an important waypoint that can help teachers and students determine how on-track each student is.

  • Frequency: 1 per semester 
  • Purpose: Assess how well student has mastered semester content. 
  • Item formats: Computer graded: MCSR, MCMR (any teacher-graded questions?) 
  • Length: Semester: 15–20 computer scored 
  • Content: skills/ideas from entire Semester 
  • Result: Grade (about 50 points per test)

Interim Assessment

If a school uses a data-driven instructional approach, interim assessments are critical components that drive instruction. These should probably not be used in any school that doesn’t already have a DDI approach as part of its culture and processes. When used as part of a DDI approach, interim assessments are purely formative, and time must be spent reflecting on results and planning how to make sense of and utilize them.

  • Frequency: 2–3 per year 
  • Purpose: Assess whether student is on track for STAAR assessment. Inform differentiated instruction. 
  • Item formats: Mirror STAAR (MCSR, MCMR) 
  • Length: About 15 computer-scored questions 
  • Content: skills/ideas from course so far with strategic spiraling and item types that match summative 
  • Result: Provide summary of results to student and teacher (no grade)
